title: What is the best Beatles album? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most of their albums are indispensable. Most of them are many people’s favorites. There is no clear best, although I have my faves. If I were introducing someone to the Beatles, I would start with a middle album - namely Rubber Soul. Their earlier albums are more primitive - pretty much all love songs - and primitive by music standards established by the latter Beatles and ever since. Their latter albums progress through ever advancing studio techniques. It is fascinating to hear their progress album by album. However, since we are going back in time and are not living those times, I think you’d get more enjoyment alternating between their more raw emotional early work and their sophisticated latter work. The highlights of Rubber Soul are (my picks, I need not remind): “Drive My Car”, “Norwegian Wood”, “Michelle”, and “In My Life”. Be sure to have the U.K versions of their albums (now standard everywhere) - as the Beatles intended - except Magical Mystery Tour which was not released as a long play album in the UK.) Ideally, take the time to play each album a few times before moving onto the next. I would play Revolver next. It did follow Rubber Soul sequentially and I think shows the greatest development in their sound between any two consecutive albums. It came out when they stopped touring and focused on producing the best possible records on vinyl. The Rolling Stone magazine ranked Revolver the best album by any rock group ever. It certainly has its gems: “Eleanor Rigby”, “Here, There, Everywhere”, “Good Day Sunshine”, “For No One”, “Got to Get You Into My Life”. It has the very psychedelic “Tomorrow Never Knows”. Now go back to their beginnings and listen to Please, Please, Me. This is Beatles at their rawest: “Twist and Shout”, “Anna (Go to Him)”, and their earliest artistic ideas: “Love Me Do”, “”P.S. I Love You”, and their first brilliant self-penned rocker “Since I Saw Her Standing There”. Many critics consider Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band their greatest achievement. The flow of the first three songs “Sgt. Peppers . . .”, “With a Little Help From My Friends”, and “Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds” along with the reprise of “Sgt. Pepper’s . . .” just before the perfect finale “A Day in the Life”, gave this album the feel of a whole album meant as one piece rather than a just collection of songs that albums were up until then. This record also includes “Fixing a Hole”, “When I’m Sixty-Four”, “Lovely Rita” and the mystical “Within You Without You”. Then go back to the innocent early days With the Beatles. Highlights: “All My Loving”, “Please Mr. Postman”, “You Really Got a Hold on Me”, “Not a Second Time”, and “Money (That’s What I Want)”. Magical Mystery Tour was originally just a double EP, but in the U.S., they added some great singles not attached to any album - particularly “Penny Lane” and “Strawberry Fields” and made a full album out of it. “Fool on the Hill” and “I Am the Walrus” are generally considered the highlights of the MMT songs. Back again to A Hard Day’s Night: highlights: the title track, “If I Fell”, “And I Love Her”, “Can’t Buy Me Love”, “You Can’t Do That”, and “I’ll Be Back”. I would play Let it Be next. Yes, it was their last release, but it was recorded mostly 2nd to last. But, musically, it belongs even before their white album. The song “Get Back” and some of the others were in a way their way to get back to the roots of their rock and roll music - without the heavy studio treatments of their previous three albums. Of course “Let it Be” and “Across the Universe” are sublime. Let it Be Naked has some refreshing alternative versions of most of these songs and others - without Phil Spector’s soppy choirs, but I’ve grown accustomed to his versions. At this point, I would break from their albums as they released them and pick up all their loose great singles from their early years. They are found on the snobbishly un-Beatles-like named Past Masters, Volume One, which includes the two songs that set off Beatlemania in the U.S.: “I Want to Hold Your Hand” and “She Loves You” - and also German versions of those songs. The package also has “I Feel Fine”, “She’s a Woman”, “I’m Down”, and my favorite “This Boy”. Likewise, the Beatles rounded up singles and B sides un-tethered to any latter day albums on a package called Past Masters, Volume Two. Both Volumes also contain alternate takes of a few songs that do appear on albums - usually the single versions of those songs. I can’t think of an alternate version here that I prefer to the album version, so, it is perfectly fine to just acquire the unique songs. The one alternative that might be worth having on your playlists would be the single / rock ’n roll version of “Revolution” = with Nicky Hopkins on the electric piano, although if I had to choose, I wouldn’t hesitate to stick with the shooby-dooby version on The Beatles. Album-less gems on this collection include “Day Tripper”, “We Can Work it Out”, “Rain”, “Lady Madonna”, “Don’t Let Me Down”, “The Ballad of John and Yoko”, and the greatest song ever made to make a sad one feel better: “Hey Jude”. In fact, the Beatles did at one point release this package around the time they broke up as The Beatles Again before that was changed shortly after to Hey Jude, until many years later: Past Masters Volume Two. The names just kept getting worse. And while you are picking out single songs, I suggest grabbing three of the four original songs on Yellow Submarine (“All Together Now”, “Hey Bulldog”, and “It’s All Too Much”) and skip the rest of the movie track. The other original song is the only Beatles song ever produced that I just don’t like at all. Next, I recommend their most underrated album: Beatles for Sale. Incredibly good songs: “No Reply”, “I’m a Loser”, “Baby’s in Black”, “I’ll Follow the Sun”, “Mr. Moonlight”, “Eight Days a Week”, “Words of Love”. Then it would be time to enjoy the wonderful world of The Beatles (aka “the white album”). Personally, this is probably the most important album in my life. It got me through the turmoil of middle school and the Vietnam War insanity. When my kids were young I sang “Good Night”, “Mother Nature’s Sun”, and “Martha, My Dear” (changed to “Margaux, My Dear” for the sake of my daughter Margaux) as lullabies. What is more rousing than “Back in the USSR”, “Birthday”, or “Helter Skelter”, or more beautiful than “Dear Prudence”, “While My Guitar Gently Weeps”, “Blackbird”, “Sexy Sadie”, or “Long Long Long” or more fun than . . . well, half the album. I for one think the soundscape “Revolution 9” is a brilliantly wonderful ride. The U.K. version of Help! is almost twice as good as the wonderful U.S. version I played over and over as a kid. You still get the title track, “The Night Before”, “You’ve Got to Hide Your Love Away”, and “Ticket to Ride”, but “Dizzy Miss Lizzy” and the most covered song in history: “Yesterday”. Finally, Abbey Road, which opens with “Come Together”, makes you fall in love with “Something”, rouses you with “Oh! Darling”, endears you with “Octopus’s Garden”, wins you completely over with “Here Comes the Sun”, takes you to dream land with “Because”, then sweeps you away with the long medley that ends with Ringo’s only drum solo followed by their only guitar dual with McCartney, Harrison, and Lennon trading licks. That is “The End” and how you should end your Beatles exploration.

I have written this elsewhere on Quora but can’t find it. For me I go back and forth between Rubber Soul and Revolver. I grew up with the Beatles but we were trying to be hard nosed street kids, so for us the early Beatles were for the girls. We listened to harder rougher stuff, Rolling Stones, Yardbirds etc. Rubber Soul changed all of that for me. Feels like I was maturing right along with the Beatles in that that Album spoke to me of different worlds, different ways of thinking and being. It is an Album of beauty and wonder to me and will always have a place in my heart because it became my entry into a world that was growing and changing along with me (and all my hormones). Revolver got down and pushed those changes! George showed up in a big way with his three songs on the album, everyone of them unique, credible and strong. No more “yeah yeah yeah” here. (no dis here, I have come to love every song written by this group appreciating them for what they were where and when.) Us hard nosed street boys could get behind this music. The world was changing fast and this was reflected in Revolver in big ways. There was a cultural shifting process that began with the Beatles in 1964. Somehow they took our music reflected it back to us then changed it. They were able to hold up a mirror for all of us reflecting the time in which we lived and the source of our feelings. They then broke the mirror and handed us back windows to see it all differently. In so many ways this to me is the power of what they accomplished. This ability, became most evident to me with Rubber Soul (as did the use of drugs theirs and mine) and crystallized with Revolver. No doubt Sgt. Pepper was an astonishing accomplishment but in someways they and the world were escaping from reality as we all rushed headlong towards a very big fall. I began high school in 1964 and graduated in 1968. I shook Bobby Kennedy’s hand two-days before he was assassinated during my last week of school. We had not had a proper chance to mourn the loss of Martin Luther King (assassinated in April of that year) and we were knocked off our feet. For me the fantasy was over and the White Album for me characterizes the breakdown that was beginning. The shift between Peppers and Magical Mystery Tour to the White Album was the shift I felt in my life. I think “I am the Walrus” captures the madness of that transition perfectly. I digress, love Rubber Soul, but it usually comes down to Revolver. Grounded, forward thinking, incredible songs, perhaps some of the best musicianship, and always always for me marking some serious turning points in the cultural upheaval that begins in 64′ with the assassination of JFK and the rise of the Beatles. Post White Album, I feel very personal about some of the songs on Let it Be (usually like this Album better than my friends) and of course the beautiful goodbye of Abbey Road concluding with The End. What a magnificent send off. But its all subjective so I stick with Revolver and to this day remain personally grateful for every note they played together.
